[Formula One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One"), abbreviated to F1, is the
highest class of [open-wheeled](/wiki/Open_wheel_car "Open wheel car") [auto
racing](/wiki/Auto_racing "Auto racing") defined by the [Fédération
Internationale de
l'Automobile](/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile
"Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile") (FIA), motorsport's world
governing body.[1] The "formula" in the name refers to a set of rules to which
all participants and cars must conform. The F1 World Championship season
consists of a series of races, known as [Grands
Prix](/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_Grands_Prix "List of Formula One Grands
Prix"), held usually on purpose-built
[circuits](/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_circuits "List of Formula One circuits"),
and in a few cases on closed city streets. The polesitter is the driver that
has qualified for a [Grand Prix](/wiki/Grand_Prix_motor_racing "Grand Prix
motor racing") in [pole position](/wiki/Pole_position "Pole position"), at the
front of the starting grid. Drivers are awarded points based on their position
at the end of each race, and the driver who accumulates the most points over
each calendar year is crowned that year's [World
Champion](/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions "List of
Formula One World Drivers' Champions"). Out of 977 completed Grands Prix (as
of the [2018 Australian Grand Prix](/wiki/2018_Australian_Grand_Prix "2018
Australian Grand Prix")), the driver that has qualified on pole position has
gone on to win the race 410 times.[2]

Qualifying is traditionally contested on the Saturday of a Grand Prix weekend
to determine the drivers' positions on the starting grid. Historically, there
have been a number of different qualifying systems; previously, each driver
was only allowed a single lap to set his qualifying time.[3] Drivers currently
have to compete in three rounds before pole position is determined. The first
round known as Q1 is contested by twenty drivers in an 18-minute session, at
the end of which the five slowest cars are eliminated. This is followed by Q2,
a 15-minute session, where the slowest five are again eliminated. The
remaining ten cars contest Q3, the final 12-minute session to determine their
places on the grid and who will sit on pole-position.[4]

[Lewis Hamilton](/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton "Lewis Hamilton") holds the record for
the most pole positions, having qualified first on 73 occasions. [Michael
Schumacher](/wiki/Michael_Schumacher "Michael Schumacher") is second with 68
pole positions.[5][Ayrton Senna](/wiki/Ayrton_Senna "Ayrton Senna") is third
with 65 poles. Senna holds the record for the most consecutive poles; he
qualified in first place eight Grands Prix in a row from the [1988 Spanish
Grand Prix](/wiki/1988_Spanish_Grand_Prix "1988 Spanish Grand Prix") to the
[1989 United States Grand Prix](/wiki/1989_United_States_Grand_Prix "1989
United States Grand Prix").[6] [Sebastian Vettel](/wiki/Sebastian_Vettel
"Sebastian Vettel") is the youngest polesitter, he was 21 years, 72 days old
when he qualified in first place for the [2008 Italian Grand
Prix](/wiki/2008_Italian_Grand_Prix "2008 Italian Grand Prix").[7] The oldest
person to qualify in pole position was [Nino Farina](/wiki/Nino_Farina "Nino
Farina"), who was 47 years, 79 days old when he was polesitter for the [1954
Argentine Grand Prix](/wiki/1954_Argentine_Grand_Prix "1954 Argentine Grand
Prix").[8] As of the [2017 Abu Dhabi Grand
Prix](/wiki/2017_Abu_Dhabi_Grand_Prix "2017 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix"), 98 drivers
have been on pole position in the 976 Grands Prix since the first [World
Championship
race](/wiki/Formula_One#Distinction_between_Formula_One_and_World_Championship_races
"Formula One"), the [1950 British Grand Prix](/wiki/1950_British_Grand_Prix
"1950 British Grand Prix").[9] From 2014 onwards the driver who achieves the
most pole positions in a season is awarded the [Pole
Trophy](/wiki/Pole_position#FIA_Pole_Trophy "Pole position"). The inaugural
Pole Trophy was won by Nico Rosberg; the 2015, 2016 and 2017 Trophies were won
by Lewis Hamilton.
